Each Friday the Reno County Health Department releases the 14 day PTR (positive test rate) and the 14 day new case average. This is the second week in a rolling two week average for schools.

14 Day PTR-9/11, 7.3%
14 Day New Case-9/11, 67

I have added a short video to this week's communication in hopes of better explaining these numbers and how we are using them.

The good news is we are showing a slight downward trend in both of these numbers from the previous week. It continues to be crucial that we all do our best to help keep our schools open by wearing masks, staying home when sick, washing hands regularly, and social distancing.

I have attached the 308 Gating Criteria in case you missed it last week.

Your students continue to do an excellent job with our safety procedures. We look forward to having a full week of school next week. Have a wonderful weekend.

Thanks again for your support of our school district!

Mike Folks

Because of a recent U.S. Department of Agriculture order, all students enrolled in USD 308 who eat breakfast or lunch in district schools will not be charged through Dec. 31.

Families who normally would pay the full rate or the reduce rate for meals will not be charged during this time. All meal charges prior to Sept. 3 will still apply. Additionally, students will have to pay for ala-carte items.

District families still need to fill out the free/reduced application because meals after Dec 31 will be charged according to their student meal status. The free/reduced application also is needed on file for families to qualify for free or reduced-price textbook fees. This application helps our district receive additional state funding needed to provide resources for our students.

COVID-19 has changed the way we support our student athletes. Most districts have seriously limited attendance at games. While we don't anticipate this being a major issue for Salthawk football at our spacious Gowans Stadium, it will be for road games.

Our USD 308 meal service for anyone ages 18 to 1 continues.

Meals will be offered from 11:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. Monday through Friday at the three locations. Meals are free for anyone 18 and younger but the student/child must be present in the vehicle, or the driver must show a Grab and Go Meal Pass. For each student/child, they will receive one lunch for that day and breakfast for the following morning. We also will allow families to pick up meal passes so that children don't have to be in the car when they receive their meals in the future.

Locations for the meals:

McCandless Elementary School, 700 N. Baker
Hutchinson Middle School – 7, 210 E. A
Hutchinson Middle School – 8, 200 W. 14th

If inclement weather threatens, we will post updated locations the day of the meal.

Lunch entrees for the week of April 27 include:
Monday: Build-Your-Own Pizza
Tuesday: Popcorn Chicken
Wednesday: Turkey Sandwich
Thursday: Bean & Cheese Burrito
Friday: PB&J

Each meal has additional items including fruit and veggies as well as milk.

Students will be visiting with their legislators, performing, and attending a press conference about the impact that theatre has on students in Kansas and beyond. Hutchinson High School will be taking 7 students to meet with our area legislators. Students attending are:Derek Norris, Azia Colvin, Josh Morris, Adriana Owens, Gabby Reid, Victoria Owens, Jasper Fast.

In honor of #YouthArtMonth, we are celebrating the district's art teachers like Hannah Norris!

Norris has taught art for the district for about 2 years. On a normal day, you can find her in her HMS-8 classroom that has wonderful murals painted on the walls helping students reach their potential.

"I love watching my students get a spark of creativity," Norris said. "When they get excited to create something, there’s nothing more rewarding."

Norris is proud to be an art teacher and says the art is vital to education because it gives students and opportunity to express themselves.

"Art is so important for students," Norris said. "It gives them a creative outlet and opportunities to work in a hands-on way that they don’t get throughout most of the school day."

It's #YouthArtMonth and we are celebrating some of the district's Art Teachers!
Debra Ringler, Art Teacher, has been teaching at Hutchinson Public Schools for 22 years.

"The most rewarding part of my job is not only teaching them all I know about art, but watching them grow, change and experience success," Ringler said.

On a normal day, you can find Ringler in her room at Hutchinson High School adorned with paper machè masks, working with students on a throwing wheel for pottery. Some of the bowls for the annual Empty Bowls fundraiser, held at Hutch Art Center, are made in her room.

"The community can help by staying on top of what the schools are doing with the art programs," Ringler said. "Another way for the community to get involved with Youth Art is to support the Empty Bowls sale that HHS students put on to help the Reno County Food Bank."

We certainly appreciate everything that Debra Ringler does for our students!
#308Pride

The second and final set of parent-teacher conferences for pre-kindergarten through sixth grade students for 2019-20 school year will be the week of Feb. 17.

Pre-kindergarten through sixth grade students attend classes full days on Monday, Feb. 17, through Wednesday, Feb. 19. Parent-teacher conferences, then, are held after school on Wednesday, Feb. 19, and all day on Thursday, Feb. 20. Students will not be in class on Feb. 20 or 21. Pre-kindergarten through sixth grade staff also will not be on duty Friday, Feb. 21.

Middle school students will be on regular schedules, Monday, Feb. 17, through Thursday, Feb. 20. HMS students will be off on Feb. 21, but staff will have a work and professional development day.

HHS will be on finals schedule the week of Feb. 17. After a regular school day on Feb. 17, HHS will have finals on Feb. 18, 19 and 20, with finals for two class periods given each day with students done each day by 11 a.m. HHS staff will have a work/professional development day on Feb. 21.

January 24 at 2:18 PM ·

Here is an update about a possible threat at HHS.

A Hutchinson Police Department investigation has led officers to believe the possible threat began with a snap chat social media posting by someone in Texas that was picked up by a Hutchinson High School student. Police in Texas have verified the Snap came from Texas. The HHS student shared that posting as well. It had nothing to do with HHS or Hutchinson.

As word spread, it became embellished with additional rumors about a video, which were investigated as well.

Staff talked with students who had direct knowledge and nothing was verified. Staff also reviewed security cameras around the HHS campus in areas where students had thought they had seen something. Nothing was ever found.

Hutchinson USD 308 has received the Commissioner’s Award from the Kansas State Department of Education for graduates’ performance.
The Commissioner's Award recognizes Kansas districts that outperform their predicted postsecondary effectiveness rate. A district's predicted postsecondary effectiveness rate factors in the degree to which identified risk factors are known to depress post-secondary success. Those factors include poverty, chronic absenteeism and student mobility.
Hutchinson Superintendent Mike Folks thanked all staff in an email for their combined work toward the award.
“We realize student success begins at a very young age and all of our schools, staff and programs play an integral role in raising a successful student,” Folks wrote. “Congratulations to everyone dedicated to improving the lives of our students. Way to go, Hutch. I'm proud of you!”

For more information go to:
http://www.usd308.com/node/1618
